content:
Consider Adding the test case below
B > C
A > C
C > B

I passed all cases even when I failed this one. I think you need a case where multiple larger letters exist for a single letter, and it matters.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I/It was giving me pain

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good entry puzzle for graphs.
You should probably reduce the constraint on n since the maximum found is 21, other than that it's pretty solid now.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find it an interesting problem, which is not so easy. I had to think about it how to properly solve the problem. And I find it sufficiently different from https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/find-the-liars.

I think this is a fairly reasonable problem for the difficulty given. Perhaps you could add some small inconvenience such as < as well as > operator or variable conditions in each line A<B >C which would make the problem seem a bit harder for novice developers.

This is very similar to https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/find-the-liars
Can you give your puzzle more uniqueness ?
Hi, I tried to use this puzzle as first as a clash of code, but people called it a bit too complicated for 5 (or 15) minutes. So I tried it again as a puzzle.
Thanks for feedback on my first try :-)

I intended to make a more or less simple problem, where the task is very clear. I did not see all the other problems so far. I think my puzzle is easier to solve and tons of easier to understand.

I don‘t know how to add uniqueness to my problem. If the other guy was faster (it seems kind of new) and you consider this as duplicate, then maybe we don‘t need it here. Although I consider it different.

I wanted to create a fairly simple problem to start with. Of course this level is "easy" and there are harder difficulties out there. But I like to go for a somewhat simple problem to start with.

If this is well received, I might try to do another version which is harder.
I don‘t understand which solution passes my tests / validation and your example not. Which solution / idea did you find?
If guys downvote my answer, but don't express their opinion further, this is totally useless.
One way to make the problem deeper would be to use additional operators, like = or >= for your equations. I don't know how complex it would become but it seems like a decent idea.

Operators like = and >= do not really help when it comes to showing a contradiction. The chain
A >= B >= C >= D >= A
shows that all variables are equal. There can't be a contradiction. You can try to task something like adding numbers and such, but if you want to deepen the complexity you can go up to a proper LP solver like done at e.g. https://github.com/coin-or/Clp

I have no idea how to extend it with having still a nice problem. So in end I would need to come up with something completely different. I also looked a bit more into the other problem and it seems really different to what I am proposing. I think you should ignore my solution and try to solve both of them.

Mine is a rather easy graph problem (is graph cylic or acylic) using inequalities to make it such that people don't just google an algorithm. His is about logic where you also use implications.

I don't know what to argue else. I don't have an easy way to make my problem different. If this problem is not good enough, just decline it.

Actually you're right, now that I have solved yours it's clearly different from the other one, cyclic graph vs boolean logic essentially.
I still think more operators would be nice to have (modulo maybe ?) but I can get behind yours as is now.
